titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Chester B. Himes Papers
titlestmt.author: by Bergis Jules and Ellen Doon

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:43

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Chester Himes Papers consist of original manuscripts, correspondence, photographs and artwork that document his long career as a writer. The manuscripts offer insight into Himes's creative process and many of them also represent the original versions and original titles for works that were later altered for publication. The bulk of the correspondence reveals Himes's relationship with the publishers and editors of his books and also offers a glimpse into the author's thoughts on his own work. The photographs and artwork document Himes's life with his family, friends and colleagues.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English, some materials in Spanish and French.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the author, 1953-1976. Gift of the author through Carl Van Vechten, G. P. Putnam's Sons, Doubleday and Book of the Month Club, 1952-1972. Gift of Lesley Himes, 1986.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Chester Himes Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Chester Himes Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: All descriptive information for writings in Series I. and Series V. was transcribed from pre-existing catalog cards.
Material in this collection formerly used the call numbers Uncat JWJ MS 12; JWJ MSS Himes; and ZAN 5 +2 V.5, V.6.
This collection was processed as part of the Beinecke Library Summer Internship Program in 2008.

bioghist.head: Chester B. Himes (1909-1984)
bioghist.p: Chester Bomar Himes was born in Jefferson City, Missouri on July 29, 1909 to Estelle Bomar Himes and Joseph Sandy Himes. He had two brothers, Edward and Joseph. Throughout his adolescent years Himes lived in Missouri, Arkansas, Georgia, Mississippi and Ohio, mainly because his father, Joseph, was a teacher who worked in these locations. Himes graduated from East High School in Cleveland, Ohio in 1926 and spent the early part of his adult life in Cleveland and Columbus, where he enrolled at Ohio State University to study medicine. He was expelled from Ohio State University in 1928 and shortly afterward was arrested, convicted for armed robbery, and sentenced, at the age of nineteen, to a twenty-five year term in prison. Himes served only part of that sentence, from 1928 to1936, at the Ohio State Penetentiary in Columbus, during which time he became a published and somewhat well-known writer. Evidently inspired to begin writing by a 1930 prison fire in which 300 inmates were killed, while in prison he published a number of articles and short stories in newspapers and magazines, most notably in Esquire .

Released from prison in 1936, he married Jean Lucinda Johnson in 1937. From 1938 to 1941 he worked for the Cleveland Daily News and the Ohio Writers' Project, for which he wrote a history of Cleveland for the WPA Guide Series. Himes moved to California in 1941 and continued writing and working at shipyards until 1944, all the while trying with little success to secure a publisher for his novel Black Sheep (later published, in 1952, as Cast the First Stone ). With the help of a Rosenwald Fellowship he was able to complete his first book, If He Hollers Let Him Go , which was published in 1945. His second book, Lonely Crusade , was published in 1947. Himes moved to Paris around 1953, and in 1955 published The Primitive . The first book of his now famous hard-boiled detective fiction series, For Love of Imabelle , which features two African American detectives from Harlem, Coffin Ed Johnson and Grave Digger Jones, was released in 1957. Himes spent the rest of his days living and writing in Europe, including stints in France, Germany and England, but primarily in Moraira on the southern coast of Spain with his second wife, Lesley Packard Himes. He published many other works including his two volume autobiography, The Quality of Hurt (1973) and My Life of Absurdity (1976). He died in Moraira, Spain on November 12, 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Chester Himes Papers consists of original manuscripts, correspondence, photographs and artwork that document his long career as a writer. The manuscripts offer insight into Himes's creative process and many of them also represent the original versions and original titles for works which were later altered for publication. The bulk of the correspondence reveals Himes's relationship with the publishers and editors of his books and also offers a glimpse into the author's thoughts on his own work. The photographs and artwork document Himes's life with his family, friends and colleagues.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Writings, 1936-1976. II. Correspondence, 1947-1980. III. Printed Material, 1947-1964. IV. Photographs and Artwork, 1953-1967. V. Estelle B. Himes Writings, undated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is arranged alphabetically by title of work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is comprised of Chester Himes's original manuscript drafts, draft fragments, and miscelleaneous notes and sketches. Some of the manuscripts and draft fragments are signed by Himes and also contain handwritten corrections. The manuscripts in this series also include the original titles that Himes had for his books. The series includes galley proofs and page proofs, some with corrections and notes from Himes and the various publishers of his books.

Some notable manuscripts in this series include, If He Hollers Let Him Go , Himes's first novel published in 1945; Lonely Crusade , his second novel, published in 1947; and Cast The First Stone , published in 1953. Also present in this series are some of Himes's short pieces of writing including an autobiographical essay and an essay on his impressions of life in Europe.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II. is arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains a small amount of Himes's incoming and outgoing correspondence. The bulk of the correspondence documents Himes's professional relationships with G.P. Putnam's Sons editor William Targ and photographer and writer Carl Van Vechten. The letters between Targ and Himes date from when Targ served as editor and editor in chief at two different publishing companies, The World Publishing Company, where he was from 1942 until 1964, and G. P. Putnam's Sons, where he worked from 1964 until 1978. The series also includes one letter from Himes to Helen Meyer, editor at Dell Publishing Co. Inc and four letters from Himes to Roslyn Targ, wife of William Targ and owner of Roslyn Targ Literary Agency Inc.

A large amount of the correspondence discusses contracts and payments for some of Himes's manuscripts and movie contracts. Some of the letters contain considerable discussion about discrepancies in payments and contracts for Himes's book, Cotton Comes To Harlem , which was turned into a movie. Other letters discuss Himes's life traveling in Europe and his life in Spain. The letters also discuss Himes's disapproval of the way publishers edited some of his books. In a letter to Helen Meyer, Himes protests the cover and descriptive copy of his book Run Man Run . Carl Van Vechten's letters discuss Himes's writings, his gifts to Yale, his travels, and their mutual friends and interests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
See: Series I. Writings, Cast the First Stone
.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes a letter from Samuel Goldwyn, Jr., to Himes, a letter from from Targ to Goldwyn, and a letter from Anthony Boucher to Targ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this series consists of clippings of reviews of Himes's second novel, Lonely Crusade . Although sales of the book in the United States did not reflect this, when Lonely Crusade was first released it caused a considerable amount of controversy. As a result, a large number of book reviews were published in major newspapers such as The New Yorker , The New York Times , The Cleveland Plain Dealer and The New York Post as well as in smaller African American newspapers and magazines such as The Chicago Defender and The Crisis . The series also includes reviews by major figures in the literary and journalism world during the mid-twentieth century including Arna Bontemps, James Baldwin, Guy Savino, William Targ and Willard Motley. Some of the clippings also discuss Himes's life, his work and his travels in Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photographs in this series document Himes's life with his family and friends. The series includes portraits of Himes, reproductions of snapshots of Himes as a child and as a teenager and also some photographs of his mother, Estelle Bomar Himes, and his brother Joseph S. Himes, Jr.. Also included in this series are photographs of Himes with Regine Fischer, and a number of images of Himes in the studio and home of his friend Walter Coleman, the American painter. Coleman's wife was the silversmith Torun Blow-Hbe, and there are several photographs of her and her work. Also included are two photographs of Himes speaking on a panel that includes Rebecca West at an event in France celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of Feux Croiss, and two photographs of Himes with French author Jean Giono.

Dates pencilled on the photographs were added by the library at the time of acquisition, and refer to letters from Himes to Carl Van Vechten, which can be found in the Carl Van Vechten Papers. These letters provide context for the photographs.
